content.description: Just to the left of Chestnut Mare, the crux of this route is surmounting the face of the bulge. It is easier if you're taller. Unlike most of the other climbs, this one does not follow a water groove.
content.protection: There are a couple of bolts, but it would be a spicy lead.
content.location: This route is 4-5 feet to the left of Chestnut Mare.

content.description: The crux is near the bottom and depends on which way you wander up the face.  Beware of wasp nests in pockets during the summer months.
content.protection: There are some bolts and some opportunities for pro in solution pockets and cracks.
content.location: This is the eastern most climb on the Cheers ledge.  From the top rappel station, this is the left-most belay station near a large shrub.  When you are on Cheers Ledge the start to this climb is the farthest right--just beyond the rappel station for the lowest cliff face.

content.description: This is the shortest of the Cheers Ledge climbs. The bulge section is short and easy.
content.protection: three bolts with opportunities for additional protection
content.location: Quarter Horse is the left most climb on the Cheers Ledge. It would be difficult to access this one from above because it is so far to the left and the rock face above the climb is covered with lichen.

content.description:
The lower portion is a mellow face climb (5.6-5.7). Then you come to the bulge. There is a high pinch on the left for your hands and almost nothing for your feet. There is a bolt at the edge of the bulge, but if you blow the crux you will likely hit the ledge below the bulge.

I've only climbed to the crux on this one. I've yet to see anyone climb the crux cleanly--even climbers who have successfully surmounted the crux of Crazy Horse and Wild Horses.
content.protection: Marginal protection. It is better to top rope this one.
content.location: At the south end of the bulge--to the left of Crazy Horse.

content.description: Down low this climb has some enjoyable thin edging and crimps. At the bulge the rock transitions to mostly friction moves.
content.protection: This route has a few bolts on it.
content.location: This route is to the left of Horse with No Name and surmounts the bulge at it right most end.

content.description: Fun edging and side pulls. The route begins at the right end of the main belay ledge (to the left of the lower rappel station). from there it follows a water groove up then trends right to a belay station. The crux is the first 25 feet.
content.protection: There are couple of bolts on this route (and some chopped bolts). The pockets provide opportunities for pro, though some of it can be finicky. There is often an active wasp nest in the pockets in the lower portion of the route.
content.location: This route begins just to the left of the rappel station located toward the right end of Cheers Ledge and then angles up and to the right.

content.description: I haven't finished this one. Start by the base of the large pine. Thin edging with minimal hands leads up to the bulge. The strenuous crux is at the highest point of the bulge and is height dependent.
content.protection: a couple of bolts and some gear.  Not really very much of either.

content.description: After a bouldery start, climb the face up to a water groove at the bulge. The crux is somewhat height dependent with good hands up high, but not much else. Follow the water groove to the bolts.
content.location: Between Mustang Sally and Wild Horses
